comments.body: This might be a new concept to you but maybe, just maybe, Mojang doesn't want bugs and glitches? Maybe
I don’t know about this one. I think it’s kind of smart.

For a visual example that's in the game, something similar to the way backing up used to make a player's body rotate, making it so that when hit it looked kind of like their shoulder was pushed back by the impact. It was a pretty simple and probably unintended effect but it was a neat addition. 
as I understand this wouldn't be That hard to implement since the only real animation is roating the torso while leaving the head and attacking arm mostly unchanged to preserve the indication of what direction the player is facing. Though that's from the perspective of an animator not a programmer.

For clarity: while in my ideal world this principle would be used for other attacks made by the player this suggestion is only about the spear.
Craftable emerald armor

I wasn't able to finish my post because of the mark limitation. There are the final notes:

Players will also have a thirsty bar on deserts. That will make them more scary to conquer. You can still explore them. It's good precalculus to storage waterbotles into your inventory, though. But it's not a necessity because there are oses on the way. They are a biome type that has been wished for a long time by the community and intriduction of the thirsty bar would make them vital for cowboys who enjoy facing chalenges whitout preparing / grinding waterbotles.  

A cool feature for the thisrty bar would also be if it wouldn't be spent at all during nights and would shink fastest when the sun is at it's highest. Also a shadow would weaken (but not cancel) dehydration. During night time there's cold on deserts so maybe the player would be threatened by freezing? There's allready freazing in minecraft in the context of powder snow. Something similar on desserts? Powder sand that can be walked upon on day but where you will sink during nights? Did I go too far from the laws of physics?

You could also add suspicious snow (and frozen mammoth's skuls) at the same time with powder sand, that would fit in to theme.

P.S. I think that thirsty bar should be an exclusive feature for desserts. Logically, players should also have it in nether since that's even hotter place. But it's allready difficult to find food from nether and there's no water so I won't reccommend adding a thirsty bar there. It would limit exploring too much. Some reason should have developed why players aren't thirsty in the nether. Maybe the nether portal has some magical powers that cause this? Maybe it drains blod in players wain's and the appearance of their skin will chance to a new variant: scorched skin. The costume would be active for all players in nether, a great lore addition.

Mojang has had the trend of avoiding to chance any old things that have remained unchanged from the start of the game and have became classic (thanks to preserving policy). Still, a game needs to change and go forward. Mounts of Mayhem is a great example that you can add new functions to old mobs and make them challenging and better fitting to the modern versions of the game whitout needing to change their classic appearance. 

Regarding to my idea where minizombie crawls from the stomatch of a dead zombiehorse:

This would be a great way shake up the fan base and show that Mojang can still suprise. It's not as much a technical way that could interrupt the old game mechanics and cause unbalancing (and therefore need long considering before it could be accepted or rejected). No, it's a background story. A cool moment, think it as a new cool new texture for an old block, or something comparable. We all love stories. This could be one way to shake up the community a bit and give the update more viewers. 

If the player watches the standing up minizombie the camera would zoom in and show a closeup of the zombies face when it uplifts it's dagger... before it charges to you! A new camera mechanic could be so cool (and a minizombie may otherwise be left whitout proper focus because it's so small and night is dark in forests)

Fully data driven custom world generation would be amazing, assuming it was the same as in Java — being able to define custom biomes / dimensions / structures / loot tables etc.

It could allow creators to release custom world-gen mash-up packs (or even a new category of package on a similar vein to resource-packs etc), so when starting a new world save, you could select a 'world-gen pack' as well. For instance, a creator could release a world-gen pack themed around halloween, complete with custom halloween biomes with spooky halloween tree structures, and the beauty of it being a world-gen pack, is that no two experiences will be exactly the same (unless the seeds are the same), compared to a regular custom map..

Assuming it was fully data-driven, it could allow the creation of worlds that are similar to legacy console worlds, super-flat worlds, worlds that consist of an endless forest and so much more. It would not replace the custom maps that are currently on the marketplace, but would be a much better value for money since it could allow for near infinite replay-ability compared to said custom maps.

The 1.21.80.22 Preview and Beta introduced Flat World presets!

  • It's now possible to select a flat world preset in the Advanced Tab of the Create New World screen when flat world mode has been enabled.

    • You can now have more variety in your flat worlds with the following presets:
      • Classic Flat
      • Tunnelers' Dream
      • Water World
      • Overworld
      • Snowy Kingdom
      • Bottomless Pit
      • Desert
      • Redstone Ready
    • We want to develop the future of flat worlds together with you, the community, by hearing your ideas over at aka.ms/mcflatworldfeedback  

    Developer's Note: This is the first batch of flat world presets we're adding. More changes are on the way, including the popular The Void preset.

It’s really frustrating that the Xbox One and Switch editions are stuck on 1.12 while older consoles like the Xbox 360 and PS Vita got 1.13. These newer consoles are more than capable of handling updates beyond 1.12, so it doesn’t make sense why they were left behind. The PS4 got the Village & Pillage update (1.14), so why not bring the Xbox One and Switch up to the same level?

I get that Bedrock is the main focus now, and it’s awesome that it brings cross-platform play and other features, but there’s still a dedicated community that loves the legacy console editions. These versions offer a different experience that many players still prefer. It feels unfair that those who stuck with these versions are missing out on content that’s available on other consoles.

Updating Xbox One and Switch to 1.14 would ensure parity across all legacy consoles and give players a sense of closure. It’s not just about having the latest content—it’s about making sure everyone who plays on these consoles has access to the same features. Plus, it would be a great way for Mojang to show that they still care about all their players, not just those who’ve moved to Bedrock or Java.

Let’s hope Mojang, Microsoft, or 4J Studios listens to the community and gives these versions the final update they deserve!

For some reason I guess it is a bug.

Because The Item Frame holds the map,
and your map (the map you are holding) just shows a green mark for a different player, not as a checkpoint/marker, You guys are just using it as checkpoint/marker.

The “Banner map marker” is a feature for marking WHILE “Item Frame map marker” is only a tip.

So there is no feature for “Map marker” in Bedrock edition it is just missing.

Parity is explained as:
“work one way on one platform, and another way on a different platform.”
BUT there is no “other way” in bedrock
Again, “Item Frame with map” is only a technique, NOT a feature for “Map marker”.

Well remember this is my opinion, My theory might be wrong or right, BUT in my research (which is googling) I found no feature for “Map marker” only in bedrock.

I hope they will add this feature in patches.

Thank You

This would be amazing. Not only for map creators but for regular players aswell. All the people who want legacy edition world sizes to be added to bedrock could just use a command to change how far they can go in their worlds.

This would be useful as I have an idea for a game called speed demon where maybe 4 or 5 people get a 10-minute head start into a world and gather resources and whatever and then the speed demon who is equipped with speed 100-1000 who has maxed out leather armor and a diamond sword chases them and the last survivor wins.

This is needed in so many ways, but I’m going to focus on realms. Why it’s needed and what features we should have.

To start

World Border should not be a cheat. As it does not give the player an advantage. This allows realms to be full survival while limiting how far a player can go.

World Border should be able to be toggled in game by admin. This allows it to be changed if admin chooses to without having to create a new world. (UI would have a number input. For example 500. Meaning world border is 500 blocks from 0,0,0 or world spawn)

Large worlds have the chance to corrupt as file size increases. Limiting the distance a player can go will greatly reduce the ability of  worlds becoming too large.

Currently the survival of a realm is based off of file size being able to be edited. Worlds periodically have to be pruned, but software has its limitations. If the file size is to large, a lot of programs will not be able to load the world or have the chance of corruption during save process.

Editing is not limited to file size, as you can create a new world and TP to far distances while keeping save file small. Editing software will not be able to load.

Map image software: World explored to far will crash software while creating a PNG image.

On my realm (Economy Realm) we periodically prune the world to 5000 allowing file size to stay manageable. But as a realms owner, this is rule that I cannot enforce. World Border would make this possible.

I can see the need for two types of world limits on Realms and Servers since things get worse as the world gets larger.

First is the Saved World Limit which would allow resource gathering beyond this point, but the chunks get reset under certain conditions such as a server restart. Also, chunks outside this limit are not included in the backup and save files.

Second is the Absolute World Limit which is the maximum range in which the player can explore the world. Forcing your way outside this limit is as dangerous as the void itself.

Both of these working together should help with the file sizes as well as helping with resources that require a somewhat rare biome such as red sand from the badlands.

Mini-Games and Adventure maps would benefit from not having to worry about players finding their way into unintended parts of the world, too.

Minecraft bedrock truly needs the world border like in Java not just in commands, but in any normal world once in about 30 million blocks in each direction, because technically most players will never get there, but for those who have survival worlds for literally years and years, some may eventually get to that point and forget that going past that can get you to fall through the blocks into the void and die, which would be devastating and some people may accidentally take that plunge. It would truly make bedrock edition worlds much safer, and more of a guarantee that nothing crazy like that can happen in survival. This would also make the performance better on Bedrock. And for those who do want to access it, make it the same on Java to use commands to move it and you could also add a gamerule on the cheats section to toggle off the effect of the world border. This would truly improve the bedrock edition.

Problem:

Sadly this feature is currently impossible with the bedrock engine. The reason is that the way it renders the world. The problem is whatever you are not looking at (whether it is behind you or a block) is not rendered. The entire point of the Glow effect is that you can see things behind blocks. If it is not rendered then it cannot make the Glow effect. (This was made so lower-end phones could run the game)

Solution:

Hopefully, the new engine (The Render Dragon) renders blocks and entities even if you are not looking at them so we can have Spectral Arrows and the Glow effect.
